context: It should be pointed out that a high yield of cell mass on a carbonaceous substrate does not mean a high cell density in the culture because of the potential toxicity of the substrate at high concentrations. The initial concentration of aromatic compounds, for instance, should be controlled at 1–2g/L or below. Otherwise, no cell growth was observed. Although xylose and other pentoses are not good substrates of R. eutropha, their derivative furfural is a good substrate. Its concentration declines quickly from initial 1 to 2g/L to below 0.01g/L in 48h as shown in Fig. 3 . Since furfural is an aldehyde (furan-2-carboxaldehyde) derived mainly from xylose, R. eutropha may also be able to use other poor substrate sugars such as arabinose after they are converted to aldehydes. This needs further investigation.
